reasoning: The critique targets an alleged inference from “moral views are fussy / the eutopia target is narrow” to “mostly-great futures are unlikely,” proposing a causal reversal where fussiness induces adaptation and thus raises the chance of eutopia. But the position’s core claim is primarily about the *shape of value functions* and the *narrowness/fragility* of near-best futures; it already explicitly allows that even a narrow target could be hit via convergence/compromise (and flags that as a separate question for the next essay). So even if the critique were right, it wouldn’t do much to undermine the main ‘no easy eutopia’ thesis. Moreover, the critique is highly speculative and doesn’t engage the essay’s key assumptions (e.g., the probability distribution conditional on no serious coordinated optimization) or provide mechanisms/evidence sufficient to materially refute the argument. It is understandable and focused, with essentially no filler.
title: Fussy moral standards may provoke adaptive convergence toward eutopia
